Gold nanoparticles supported on carbon coated magnetic nanoparticles; a robustness and effective catalyst for aerobic alcohols oxidation in water Shima Karami Investigation a Farhad Kabiri Esfahani Conceptualization Validation Resources Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Visualization Supervision a ⁎ Babak Karimi Conceptualization Validation Writing – review & editing Supervision b c ⁎⁎ a Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Sciences, University of Zanjan, Zanjan 45371-38791, Iran Department of Chemistry Faculty of Sciences University of Zanjan Zanjan 45371-38791 Iran aDepartment of Chemistry, Faculty of Sciences, University of Zanjan, Zanjan 45371-38791, Iran b Department of Chemistry, Institute for Advanced Studies in Basic Sciences (IASBS), PO-Box 45195-1159, Prof. Sobouti Boulevard, Zanjan 45137-6731, Iran Department of Chemistry Institute for Advanced Studies in Basic Sciences (IASBS) PO-Box 45195-1159, Prof. Sobouti Boulevard Zanjan 45137-6731 Iran bDepartment of Chemistry, Institute for Advanced Studies in Basic Sciences (IASBS), PO-Box 45195-1159, Prof. Sobouti Boulevard, Zanjan 45137-6731, Iran c Research Center for Basic Sciences & Modern Technologies (RBST), Institute for Advanced Studies in Basic Sciences (IASBS), Prof. Sobouti Boulevard, Zanjan 45137-66731, Iran Research Center for Basic Sciences & Modern Technologies (RBST) Institute for Advanced Studies in Basic Sciences (IASBS) Prof. Sobouti Boulevard Zanjan 45137-66731 Iran cResearch Center for Basic Sciences & Modern Technologies (RBST), Institute for Advanced Studies in Basic Sciences (IASBS), Prof. Sobouti Boulevard, Zanjan 45137-66731, Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Chemistry, Institute for Advanced Studies in Basic Sciences (IASBS), PO-Box 45195-1159, Prof. Sobouti Boulevard, Zanjan 45137-6731, Iran. Department of Chemistry Institute for Advanced Studies in Basic Sciences (IASBS) PO-Box 45195-1159, Prof. Sobouti Boulevard Zanjan 45137-6731 Iran Three kinds of gold nanoparticles supported by carbon-coated magnetic nanoparticles were prepared using distinct reduction processes and appropriate quantities of carbon support. Among them, an active and magnetically recoverable catalyst known as Fe3O4@C@Au(H) was instrumental in the aerobic oxidation of alcohols in water, where it produced carbonyl compounds with high selectivities without the formation of any carboxylic acids in the case of primary alcohol. The recovered Au catalyst can be used efficiently and quickly in ten successive runs without a noteworthy decrease in activity and, simply isolated from the water by using an external magnetic at the end of the process. In particular, the possibility to carry out the reaction in water, and simultaneously, the straightforward protocol for recycling via the easy and rapid separation method makes this catalytic system a credible candidate towards the target of green chemistry. Graphical abstract Based on the fifth and ninth principles of the twelve principles of green chemistry, water as a “green solvent” was used in aerobic oxidation of alcohols and Au nanoparticles catalyst easily recovered ten consecutive runs from the reaction mixture. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Gold nanoparticles Carbon Aerobic oxidation of alcohols Water Magnetic nanoparticles Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The last decades have witnessed gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) are being extensively used as catalyst materials owing to their distinctive properties and remarkable potential that is directly related to their particle size [1]. Numerous research teams have recently shown that the catalytic efficiency of AuNPs is regulated by their shape and size, in addition by their interaction with the support surface [2]. Catalyst support takes a leading role in supported metal catalysts to allow the use of supported metal as an active catalytic center. A perfect catalyst supports should have chemical stability, high surface area as well as the capability for suitable dispersing metal particles over the surface. Furthermore, the physical and chemical features of supports influence the catalytic activity of supported metals, resulting in the supported metal catalysts' specific traits [3]. In this respect, many materials are often used as support to immobilized of metal, namely alumina [4], silica [5], TiO2 [6], polymers [7], and carbon [8]. Carbon materials, in particular, are favorable catalytic supports for metal nanoparticles due to their excellent aqueous stability, simplicity of surface modification by integrating other elements, large surface area, and low cost [9]. Notably, to easily recover carbon support from the reaction medium, it is possible to coated carbon on magnetic nanoparticles because one of the exciting aspects of the catalyst supports is that they can be quickly recovered from the reaction media. Gold nanoparticles that are supported by other materials are highly effective catalysts in many organic processes. They have been well investigated for fundamental transformations, essentially selective oxidation of alcohols [10], CO oxidation [11], propylene epoxidation [12], chemoselective reduction of nitroarenes [13], production of hydrogen peroxide [14], coupling reaction [15], and wide diversities of commercially critical synthetic protocols. Selective alcohols oxidation is one of the most beneficial organic transformations due to the resulting carbonyl compounds are valuable intermediates in producing a broad range of useful materials, namely fine chemicals, pharmaceuticals, and agricultural chemicals. Alcohols have traditionally been oxidized using stoichiometric reagents and typically carried out in chlorinated solvents that produce metal waste [16]. To address these shortcomings, a plentiful amount of research has focused on building more efficient, recoverable, and environmentally acceptable processes based on transition-metal catalysts for powerful aqueous-phase alcohols oxidation using O2 as the ultimate oxidant [17]. Consequently, from green chemistry and economic point of view, it would significantly progress to employ water and O2 as the abundant solvent and oxidant, respectively. In this vein, creating novel reusable catalysts for selective alcohols oxidation in water employing O2 as the oxidant should pique interest from organic synthesis and green chemistry perspectives. As a result of this, we have recently developed several supported catalytic systems based upon Au nanoparticles in the aerobic alcohols oxidation [18]. Furthermore, we have found that the use of carbonaceous materials as support for metal nanoparticles can eventually boost the catalytic performance of the materials in several catalytic applications [19]. In continuation to these studies, we were encouraged to immobilize gold nanoparticles on carbon-coated magnetic nanoparticles to ameliorate the catalytic activity of Au-supported carbon for the alcohols oxidation in water with the benefit of easy and quick separation expected from magnetic systems. For this reason, gold nanoparticles were generated and stabilized using three different paths on the Fe3O4@C magnetic nanoparticles (Scheme 1 ). Firstly, the core-shell magnetic nanoparticles were synthesized, and then NaAuCl4 was added to it, and finally, gold nanoparticles were obtained by applying sodium borohydride as a reducing agent (Scheme 1-a). To make gold nanoparticles in a second approach, benzyl alcohol was used as a reducing agent. (Scheme 1-b). In the last method, the Au salt was added to the mixture of iron oxide and carbon precursor before calcination, and gold nanoparticles formed in the carbon layer simultaneous calcifying (Scheme 1-c). 2 Experimental section Each chemical was purchased from a commercial provider and used exactly as supplied. The prepared materials were confirmed by scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM TESCAN MIRA3) and transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM Zeiss Libra). To evaluate the quantity of gold in the catalyst, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry was utilized (ICP-MS, Varian). FT-IR spectra of prepared materials were taken by the Bruker Vector 22 apparatus. The magnetic properties were recorded at room temperature by applying a vibrating sample magnetometer (Meghnatis Daghigh Kavir, Iran). Gas chromatography with a flame ionization detector (Varian CP-3800) was used in conjunction with reaction monitoring. 2.1 Synthesis of magnetic nanoparticles (Fe3O4) Based on a typical preparation technique, 5.4 g of FeCl2·6H2O and 2 g of FeCl3·4H2O were dissolved by sonication for 30 min in 25 mL of HCl (2 M) at room temperature. Subsequently, 40 mL of aqueous ammonia (25%) was added gradually over a half hour to the solution. For 40 min, the resultant mixture was mixed at ambient temperature in an argon atmosphere. Additionally, separated magnetic nanoparticles were rinsed with water and ethanol and vacuum dried to achieve the product [20]. 2.2 Preparation of Fe3O4@C@Au(N) catalyst with sodium borohydride 50 mg of obtained Fe3O4 particles were dispersed in water, and 1 g cellulose was added to this solution under stirring. For 14 h, the corresponding blend was stirred under ambient conditions. An external magnet separated Magnetic-cellulose, rinsed with water, and dried at 80 °C for 8 h, then calcinated at 450 °C for three hours. Then the carbon-coated magnetic nanoparticles were dispersed in water and stirred at ambient temperature for two hours. After that, it was continuously stirred for 2 h in ice water. At the same time, 0.05 g of NaAuCl4 dissolved in 1 mL deionized water (DW) and prepared an aqueous solution of gold salt. At ambient temperature, the gold salt solution was added to the mixture and vigorously stirred for approximately 1.5 h. In the final step, 0.002 g NaBH4 was dissolved in 1 mL of water, and a fresh reducing agent solution was prepared. Then added this solution to the reaction mixture, and after 5 min, Fe3O4@C@Au(N) was collected using an external magnet, thoroughly rinsed with water, and dried at 80 °C for five hours. 2.3 Preparation of Fe3O4@C@Au(B) with benzyl alcohol Fe3O4@C@Au(B) was prepared in the same procedure as Fe3O4@C@Au(N). For this reason, 50 mg of the Fe3O4@C was disseminated in water and stirred for two hours at ambient temperature. After that, 0.05 g NaAuCl4 in 1 mL deionized water was dissolved and added to the above solution. 3 mL of benzyl alcohol was slowly added to the mixture, which was vigorously stirred, and then it was stirred at ambient temperature for about 2 h. After that, the reaction was refluxed under argon for 12 h. Finally, using an external magnet, the Fe3O4@C@Au(B) nanoparticles were isolated from the mixture and thoroughly rinsed with ethanol and water before being dried at 80 °C for five hours. 2.4 Preparation of Fe3O4@C@Au(H) catalyst 0.05 g of the resulting magnetic nanoparticles were dispersed in water, followed by adding 1 g cellulose and stirring for 6 h at ambient temperature. Then it was mixed with an aqueous solution of 0.05 g NaAuCl4 in 1 mL deionized water for eight hours. Magnetic-cellulose-Au was separated and rinsed with water, dried at 80 °C for eight hours, and then calcinated at 450 °C for three hours. 2.5 Preparation of Fe3O4@Au catalyst In a typical preparation procedure, a solution of 0.1 g of HAuCl4·3H2O, 10 mL oleylamine, and 10 mL tetralin was prepared at 20 °C and stirred for 10 min [21]. Afterward, a sonication was used to generate a combination of 1 mL oleylamine, 1 mL tetralin, and 1 mmol TBAB, which was quickly injected into the aforesaid solution and, for an hour, was mixed at ambient temperature. After that, ethanol was used to precipitate the Au NPs, which were then separated by centrifugation. The Au NPs were re-dispersed in hexane before being recovered by centrifugation and ethanol addition. Subsequently, 20 mg of the resulting Au NPs in 1 mL hexane were added to a solution of 1 mL oleic acid, 1 mL oleylamine and, 20 mL of 1-octadecene. To remove hexane, under nitrogen flow, the reaction was heated to 120 °C. Following that, 0.1 mL [Fe(CO)5] was added into the solution and heated under the N2 atmosphere at 300 °C for 30 min. The Au-Fe3O4 NPs were then formed by cooling the mixture to room temperature in the air. Finally, so as to precipitate the Au-Fe3O4 nanoparticles, isopropanol was added to the reaction, and the Fe3O4 nanoparticles were recovered by centrifugation after the precipitation had formed. 2.6 The method for the aerobic alcohols oxidation using Fe3O4@C@Au The aerobic alcohols oxidation was performed in a 10 mL two-necked round-bottomed flask, alcohols (1 mmol), NaOH (1 mmol), Fe3O4@C@Au (0.5–1.5 mol%) and water (3 mL) were charged and stirred under oxygen atmosphere at 70 °C. A gas chromatograph was used to monitor the reaction. 2.7 The reusability test of Fe3O4@C@Au catalyst In a two-neck round bottom flask, benzyl alcohol (1 mmol), sodium hydroxide (1 mmol), Fe3O4@C@Au (0.5 mol%), and 3 mL distilled water were combined and heated to 70 °C in an oil bath under an O2 atmosphere. Subsequently, the catalyst was separated from water using a magnet at the reaction's end and rinsed with 3 mL ethanol. For 10 consecutive cycles, the catalyst had no significant decline in efficiency. 3 Results and discussion To prepare the Fe3O4@C@Au materials, initially, magnetite nanoparticles were prepared by a known method [20]. After that, the resulting Fe3O4 nanoparticles were allowed to mix under room temperature and vigorous stirring with a suitable cellulose concentration to provide a uniform mixture of magnetic nanoparticles and cellulose [22]. Subsequently, carbonization was performed under an inert atmosphere of argon at 450 °C for 3 h. The resulting Fe3O4@C was impregnated in an aqueous solution of NaAuCl4 accompanied by reduction of the Au species by using benzyl alcohol or sodium borohydride to give Fe3O4@C@Au(B) 1 and Fe3O4@C@Au(N) 2, respectively. For comparison, gold nanoparticles supported on core-shell Fe3O4@C were also produced under thermal conditions. To do this, the magnetic nanoparticles were mixed with cellulose in water, and then NaAuCl4 was added to the mixture. Then, the carbonization of the magnetic-cellulose-Au composite at 450 °C provided the respected Fe3O4@C@Au(H) 3 catalyst, in which it is supposed that the reduction of Au species to gold nanoparticles could have occurred during the carbonization stage. Various techniques characterized the structure of the most active prepared catalyst, including vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM), Fourier-transform IR spectroscopy (FT-IR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopic (EDX), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and inductively coupled plasma (ICP). Using a VSM at ambient temperature and a magnetic field of up to 10,000 Oe, the magnetic properties of Fe3O4, Fe3O4@C, and Fe3O4@C@Au(H) 3 catalysts were examined. The saturated magnetization amounts of Fe3O4, Fe3O4@C, and Fe3O4@C@Au (H) samples are 57, 55, and 52 emu/g, respectively (Fig. 1 ). The surface coating of magnetic Fe3O4 nanoparticles was clearly responsible for the consistent lowering of saturation magnetization, as predicted. The hysteresis curve for the composites shows that these materials are paramagnetic at room temperature. It should be emphasized that among different Fe3O4@C@Au samples, Fe3O4@C@Au (H) 3 manifested the highest catalytic activity, and this is the primary reason that we performed only the analysis for this catalyst (vide infra). FT-IR spectra of 3 showed characterization peaks for C = C and aliphatic C–H, which verifies successful carbon immobilization on the surface of magnetic nanoparticles (Fig. 2 ). Scaning electron microscopy was used to examaine the morphology of the produced composite materials. The nanocatalyst was discovered to have a spherical shape with a particle size distribution of 25–40 nm (Fig. 3 a). EDS was used to produce quantitative elemental compositions and mapping pictures for the purpose of identifying the C and Au distributions (Fig. 3b, 3c). As can be seen, the gold nanoparticles loaded on the core-shell magnetic nanoparticles were equally dispersed on the nanometer scale. Furthermore, the results of the EDX analysis establish the attendance of gold nanoparticles on the catalyst (Fig. 4 ). It is worth mentioning that ICP analysis of acid-washed samples of 3 also showed the existence of Au in the catalyst, and the calculated amount of the Au was to be 0.084 mmol Au g − 1. Moreover, transmission electron microscopy was applied to study 3 in order to acquire a better knowledge of its structure. As is evident, Fe3O4@C nanoparticles have a well-defined spherical structure with a comparatively narrow size distribution (Fig. 5 ). The XPS method was used to elucidate the nature of Au NPs in Fe3O4@C@Au. The peaks at about 84–87.4 eV can correspond to the spin-orbit split components of the Au 4f7/2-Au 4f5/2 levels in the X-ray photoelectron spectrum reveal the pure Au metallic state in the fresh catalyst (Fig. 6 a). Likewise, high-resolution C 1 s XPS spectra of 3 clearly show three peaks that corresponding to carbon atoms in different functional groups. The prominent peak placed at 284.58 eV corresponds to delocalized sp2-hybridized carbon atoms, while the two remaining peaks at 286.18 and 288.68 eV are referred to as carbon atoms CO and C = O, respectively (Fig. 6b). The whole of these observations authenticated the successful stabilization of metallic AuNPs onto the Fe3O4@C nanoparticles. It is proposed that the immobilization of AuNPs on the surface of carbon-coated Fe3O4 could result in a high metal loading and proper distribution of catalytically active Au nanoparticles on the support [23]. In addition, many reports are highlighting the fact that due to the exceptional stability of carbon materials against aqueous acidic and basic solutions. Therefore, we expected that the Fe3O4@C@Au system might provide a suitable Au catalyst for fundamental organic processes in water as a green and safe solvent [24]. Hence, our focus was on how produced catalysts performed in the benzyl alcohol oxidation in an O2 atmosphere, with specific attention paid to whether water might be used as a green solvent. Fe3O4@C@Au(B) 1, which was made by simple dispersion of Fe3O4@C in an aqueous solution of NaAuCl4 accompanied by reduction of the Au species by using benzyl alcohol, showed poor activity at 70 °C even after 24 h, affording benzaldehyde in meager yield of 30% (Table 1 , entry 1). Furthermore, no remarkable increase in activity was obtained by increasing the catalyst loading or the reaction temperature (Table 1, entries 2 and 3). Next, Fe3O4@C@Au(N) 2 was used as catalyst instead of 1 under otherwise the same reaction conditions. It was found that by changing the reducing agent, no remarkable improvements were observed in the catalytic performance of 2, and the benzyl alcohol oxidation under O2 at 70 °C for 24 h occurred in only 40% of benzaldehyde (Table 1, entry 4). Unfortunately, the conversion was not substantially improved against rising the reaction temperature or loading of 2 (Table 1, entries 5 and 6). In all respects, these results imply that the gold nanoparticles synthesized by these methods are not appropriately active catalysts for the present transformation. In the next step, the efficiency of 3 was studied under the condition demonstrated in entry 1 of Table 1. Interestingly, it was found that 3 is a remarkably more effective catalyst, and the aerobic benzyl alcohol oxidation proceeded considerably better at 70 °C within 12 h (Table 1, entry 7). As a result of comparing the activities of prepared catalysts, it was discovered that 1 and 2 had much lower activity in the aerobic benzyl alcohol oxidation (Table 1, entries 1 and 4). These encouraging findings prompted us to investigate the effects of various catalyst loadings, temperatures, and bases (Table 1, entries 8–14). To delve further into the carbon shell's critical role in the catalytic activity of gold nanoparticles, different amounts of cellulose were then examined as a carbon source. Interestingly, the results demonstrated that the use of higher or lower cellulose content than that used in catalyst 3, the efficiency of the catalysts was significantly reduced (Table 1, entries 15–16). To further clarify the role of the carbon layer on the activity of the Fe3O4@C@Au and to make a clear comparison, we prepared gold nanoparticles on Fe3O4 [21], and then the activity of this catalyst was investigated in aerobic benzyl alcohol oxidation under the same reaction condition with 3. We found that the Au@Fe3O4 has essentially negligible activity in aerobic alcohols oxidation in water (Table 1, entry 17), which demonstrates that the carbon layer has a significant impact on gold nanoparticle catalytic performance. These findings demonstrate that the carbon support of Fe3O4@C@Au has a direct impact on its catalytic activity. Eventually, between the several reaction conditions studied, 3 (0.5 mol%), 70 °C, and NaOH (1 equiv.) was determined to be the best. After we had the optimum reaction conditions, we could further investigate our catalytic protocol's scope and limitations (Table 2 ). Along this line, numerous primary alcohols with electron-withdrawing or electron-donating groups such as NO2, Br, Cl, Me, iPr, and OMe (Table 2, entries 2–8), as well as heteroatoms like oxygen and sulfur (Table 2, entries 9–10), or functional groups that were sensitive to conversion, namely an allylic moiety (Table 2, entry 11), were quickly converted into the appropriate aldehyde with good to exceptional yields and selectivity. Additionally, it is revealed that the current approach works well with tough secondary benzylic and aliphatic alcohols, yielding good to exceptional yields of the ketones (Table 2, entries 12–16). Although Fe3O4@C@Au(H) (3) operates at higher temperatures than other gold nanoparticle-based catalysts that have carried out the aerobic alcohols oxidation in water, namely Au:PVP [25], Au:PoPD [26], PMAS/Au [27], Au/NG-4.0 [28] and Au/PDVB [29], the lower loading of catalyst and the high selectivity of 3 is remarkable. Simple recycling and recovery of supported catalysts from aqueous media, in particular, are critical concerns from the standpoint of sustainable chemistry. In this context, we studied the catalyst's recycling capability during the aerobic benzyl alcohol oxidation. After completing the first run, 3 was effortlessly isolated from the reaction and rinsed with water and ethanol prior to performing another reaction. After recovering the catalyst, It was promptly utilized for at least 10 reaction cycles under the same conditions without significant activity loss (Fig. 7 ), which demonstrates the efficient immobilizing of gold nanoparticles on carbon-coated magnetic nanoparticles. Aside from that, it is essential to note that, according to ICP analysis, the amount of leached Au species in the recycling test (runs 3 and 10) and the final extract of ethyl acetate in the final extraction phase was minuscule. Additionally, After ten runs, ICP analysis confirmed that the Au concentration of the catalyst remained consistent, indicating that there was no decline in the Au content of the catalyst after ten cycles (0.083 mmol Au g − 1). 4 Conclusion In conclusion, three types of gold nanoparticles supported on carbon-coated magnetic nanoparticles are described: Fe3O4@C@Au(B) 1, Fe3O4@C@Au(N) 2, and Fe3O4@C@Au(H) 3. The aerobic alcohols oxidation in water without a co-organic solvent is used to compare the catalytic efficiency of these catalytic systems. Amongst them, catalyst 3 is significantly more selective in the oxidation of alcohols, resulting in good to exceptional yields and selectivities for the appropriate carbonyl compound derivatives without creating any acids in the instance of primary benzyl alcohols. The inclusion of carbon as support is thought to offer a suitable distribution of Au nanoparticles on the support's surface and a stable dispersion of the catalyst in water as the reaction solvent. In particular, it is crucial to highlight that Fe3O4@C@Au(H) can be simply isolated from the aqueous phase by using a magnet and that it be able to be employed efficiently for up to ten consecutive runs without experiencing a significant reduction in activity. Altogether, this catalytic system becomes a credible contender for the goal of green chemistry since it can perform the reaction in net water and has a simple recycling strategy using a simple separation technique. coredata.dc:description: Three kinds of gold nanoparticles supported by carbon-coated magnetic nanoparticles were prepared using distinct reduction processes and appropriate quantities of carbon support. Among them, an active and magnetically recoverable catalyst known as Fe3O4@C@Au(H) was instrumental in the aerobic oxidation of alcohols in water, where it produced carbonyl compounds with high selectivities without the formation of any carboxylic acids in the case of primary alcohol. The recovered Au catalyst can be used efficiently and quickly in ten successive runs without a noteworthy decrease in activity and, simply isolated from the water by using an external magnetic at the end of the process. In particular, the possibility to carry out the reaction in water, and simultaneously, the straightforward protocol for recycling via the easy and rapid separation method makes this catalytic system a credible candidate towards the target of green chemistry.
coredata.dc:title: Gold nanoparticles supported on carbon coated magnetic nanoparticles; a robustness and effective catalyst for aerobic alcohols oxidation in water
